Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2016 07:27AM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello, When I was first diagnosed with bone mets (diffuse), I went on arimidex and had radiation to my hip. I expected the pain to resolve, but it actually got worse for about 2 1/2 months after starting the arimidex. My tumor markers were decreasing this entire time. In retrospect I attribute the pain to tumor flare. I've been pain free for more than a year - something that I never thought would happen during that 2 1/2 months. I can't say what is causing your pain, but it might be tumor flare? Maybe your onc. can prescribe some different type of pain medication. I was taking vicodin and ibuprofen and that worked for me, allowed me to continue work, but it was difficult. I hope your pain resolves soon,

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 01:20AM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello All, I start my chemo in 6 hours (TCx4).  I've  been up since 2am b/c of the dexamethasone, but I expected this b/c my Mom reacted the same way.  Was really nervous last week, but now I'm just so ready to get started (was supposed to start yesterday, but was posponed due to snow, I'm in NJ). I considered trying the fasting.  If my SE's are bad I will definitely try it next round.  Please let us know how it goes. Good Luck to everyone this month!  Funny - My son has autism, he's 18, he's verbal.  He always is not happy when I get my hair cut "Mom's have long hair" (He remembers a picture from when he was a baby, I was in my 20's and my hair was long).  Kids with autism tend to be rigid in their thinking.  I've been wearing my scarves around the house just so he gets used to seeing them.  I got my hair cut to match the style of my wig.  I really am pleased with the cut, but I got home and he scowls at me and says "You look as old as Hillary Clinton"  We all rolled on the ground, sorry Hillary!!!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 04:27PM ScienceGirl wrote: What are you all rinsing with, I'm really scared of getting mouth sores.  I did try to do the ice chips as much as possible. sicst - love the bracelets! webu - I did the same thing and it was a bit embarrassing, my medicine closed has never been so well stocked.  There is no way (I hope) that I will be taking everything I bought. I love Ativan for sleep, never tried Tylenol PM.  Annie, sorry you had a trying day, maybe tomorrow will be better.  good luck (((hug)))

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 06:45AM ScienceGirl wrote: UTMom-so sorry you were in the hospital. Thank God that you were though and the infection never got worse, but 7 days! That's a long time! My WBC also went to 0, and I got a mild fever, but my onc let me try antibiotics at home (just last night), temp is good today, but don't feel like I'm out of the woods yet. I'll be getting Neulasta next time, you too? I hope that prevents this craziness for us. I think we might be chemo twins, b/c the constipation was the worst part for me too. AliT-Love the picture! We tried no Neulasta with my first treatment, I guess some people don't need it? I will definitely be getting from now on since my WBC went to 0. I had a bit of weird head pain, kinda like squeezing or a really bad headache but just around the outside of the head, luckily it was brief. Cblue-Oh my, can they do something to help the impaction from recurring? Good luck to you and thank goodness we only have x4!! Webu-all the trouble of getting a port and you need an IV anyways, NOT FAIR!! My mom reacted badly to the steroids and they ended up lowering the dose for her. It seems like everytime I see the onc I come away with a new pill to take, this really bothers me, I hardly ever even took an aspirin before all of this! Mouth sores : ( hang in there Baf-wishing you super high WBC on Wednesday! Suz- today is Sat, hope you feel great today thinking of you all today, ((((((((((HUG))))))))))
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 06:49AM ScienceGirl wrote: amara - so sorry you are joining our club.  Make sure you are comfortable with your oncologist and feel like you can talk to them.  I actually met with mine 4 times before starting chemo, and she was patient with me everytime!  Add your diagnosis to your profile, ie ER, HER2 status, size, that changes what questions you will be asking your onc.  You should have some of this info from your biopsy report.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 07:05PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello All, Can I play devil's advocate?  Maybe supplements that lessen side effects are protecting normal cells from death, maybe they are also protecting cancer cells? "the use of antioxidant supplements during chemotherapy and radiation treatment should be discouraged because of the possibility of tumor protection and reduced survival."   Acetyl-l-carnitine is an antioxidant. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18505970 Sorry, this is probably not helpful and just adds to the many unknowns we have to live with : ( I certainly don't want to have to live with permanent neuropathy!  Maybe it's worth the risk to take the acetyl-l-carnitine, if the neuropathy gets to a certain point?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 03:55PM ScienceGirl wrote: UTMom - so sorry you were in the hospital!  Thanks for the tips, I especially like #5, it's so easy to blame ourselves for overdoing or whatever, but it  probably would have been no matter what.  I'm waiting for my nadir too see if the Neulasta has worked this time, really anxious.  It's funny how differently we all react to the same agents.  (((((HUGS)))))))))) right back at ya.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 04:20PM ScienceGirl wrote: TCx4; started 1/13;  TX2 day 16 So funny that you guys mentioned tooth pulling. I called today and scheduled for next week to have one pulled. It's an old root canal that has gotten infected with each round of chemo (2). Nowhere near the pain that EmilyinOntario had, just a nagging low grade infection, but that makes me nervous. My onc said that the chemo would aggrevate any issues like that. tfinn99 - Keep going! I so felt like quiting too. My second TX was awful. I'm starting to dread the third and it's still a week away. Let's think that TX 3 for you will be way better because your cold will be gone. I think we are all becoming experts at this chemo thing, our coping skills are getting better each round as well as our management of SE's. Kim61- Your pic is great! On deciding on your surgery, get as much information as you can and go in to talk to your surgeon as many times as you need. I can share my reasons for my BMX if your interested, just PM me. DancingMom - I have my moments of completely not coping at all!!! You are not alone. During my bad week, every dish in the house was dirty! I didn't have the energy to load the dishwasher. House was a complete wreck. You are not alone. AimeeMac - I got Lorazepam (ativan) shortly after my diagnosis, because I wasn't sleeping. It worked wonders for me, I only took it a few times, when I couldn't sleep, or before procedures. No real side effects that I noticed. Really helped quiet the racing mind. Thought I would take it before chemo, but haven't needed to. ProudMom - Hurray for last AC!!!!! Yippee! Good luck to all who are starting their hair loss week, it is weird how 'patches' at a time seem to hurt and it doesn't all fall out at the same time. This will pass and it's kind of a relief when it's over.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

I'm 4 weeks past my last infusion.  I started rads this week.  I'm going to start acupuncture next week to hopefully help with the continued fatigue I'm battling.  I'll let you know if that works.  To those who have upcoming MX or BMX.  I had my BMX in November.  It was so much easier than chemo!!  Try not to worry. Thinking of you all
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 03:04PM ScienceGirl wrote: ck_moma, My dogs are interested in my wig too!  I can see it in their eyes that they want to get a hold of this new hairy 'beast' and take it out.  I told everyone at work to let me know if my wig is on crooked or not.  I just hope that it's not to uncomfortable to wear all day.  I'll find out in about 14 days.  Jane - Good Luck on Monday and on Thursday.  This is a big week for you, you can do it!  Just remember all your beautiful hair will be making someone very happy. I'm on day 3 after my first TC, my tongue feels funny, like metal/burned but just at the tip, weird.  Doesn't really hurt just strange.  Other than that and a little constipation feeling good enough to do the laundry, yipee  (I really need to get a life) Sylvia, I'm sorry that you also have to do chemo after your radiation.  What a nasty surprise especially if you thought you were done.  Hang in there
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 11:05AM ScienceGirl wrote: So today I got the third shot of neupogen, my WBC are essentially at zero.  Next round we will do Neulasta before I get this neutropenic.  I'm missing a big family party tomorrow, just too scared to be around a lot of people (hugging and kissing), if I spike a fever, it's straight to the hospital, yikes.  I am having bone pain, hips and lower back like slcst12.  I can't take aleive or tylenol b/c it would mask a fever, so I got the big guns - oxycontin.  Just took one and I'm looking forward to a painfree drug induced nap! I only worked 2 half days this week.  So not what I was expecting, I really hope I can go to work next week some full days! AimeeMac - good luck tonight, rock the bald : ) bdavis - hang in there, it sounds like you're doing great!  (I used to live in Kingston off of rt27, now in Scotch Plains - brace yourself, more snow on Tues) JulieH - thank you for all the tips, I feel like your our Mom on this thread : )
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 05:08PM ScienceGirl wrote: webu- YIKES is right.  I told my onc today about the vision, and she looked at me ( as usual ) like she's never heard of it! I'm only day 14 after my 1st TC and today at work I ran my hand through my hair and a bunch came out.  I sat there staring at my hand, I couldn't believe it, I thought it would be later.  Then I proceeded to do it over and over just to see how much would come out.  I showed my cubical mate my new trick and she was so upset!  Everyone is conviced my hair will grow back all gray, how RUDE. (now I don't have any grays - if it comes back gray who cares, I've earned every strand!) Talking about books, I've heard that "Emperor of all maladies: A Biography of Cancer"  is good. Not sure if this is the appropriate time for reading it though?  Anyone else an avid reader?  on Goodreads?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 05:23PM ScienceGirl wrote: Lorenar - thanks for posting, day 6 is the WORST, hang in there. Webu - I agree with you, MaryMeg can post all she wants about walks in the park and sunny days : )  Please keep it up, it's been snowing twice a week here in NJ JeanH, how nice to have all that support while getting your wig, I bet they helped you pick a really nice one. JulieH, How does your head feel?  I chickened out and didn't shave my head this morning (today's day 17).  Hubby hacked it with scissors, about 2inches all around.  Wore a hat to the grocery store, but felt tight on my head which is still a bit sore.  At home I had to go without a head covering, freaking the kids out (13 and 18), but we just joked about it, and continued our day.  Maybe tomorrow I will go for the buzz.  Monday will be the wig for sure at work, really dreading that. Anniemom, I had decadron and was fine.  From these boards, it seems that people really like the Emend. baf4292, How is your arm now?  How awful, did the swelling go away quickly.  I bet they'll be extra careful with you from now on.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 03:34PM ScienceGirl wrote: TCx4; cycle 2 day20 golfergrandma - if you just started shedding today, my guess is that you will be OK for dinner tomorrow night.  Good Luck the next few days, I found I was relieved when my hair was finished falling out! Steroids - I take two the night before chemo and 2 the morning of, and that's it.  My onc did say that there are different regimes.  I don't get a steroid high, don't feel jittery and have no trouble sleeping.  I guess I'm really lucky.  My Mom had such terrible reaction to the steroids that they ended up lowering her dose to just 1/4 of the initial amount. JulieH - how bad is the tremor?  I have a muscle twitching on my face that won't stop (3 days now) wondering if I should mention this to onc.  I feel like a hypochondriac sometimes, but I guess we are allowed to be hyper aware during this. Ladies, stool softeners are your friend!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 04:47PM ScienceGirl wrote: TCx4; cycle 3 day 1 AliT - 2 of my 3 oncologist opinions recommended TCx4 for me.  My onc says there is no evidence that 6 is better than 4 - I don't think it has been studied head to head.  Right now (Ithink) that x4 is the accepted regimen.  There is a clinical study comparing TCx6 to TACx6, and I see on these boards that lots are doing x6 as well as x4, so it's a good question.  I was considering doing 6 rounds, because hey, the more the better, right, but that isn't always true.  Now that I'm feeling terrible during this ( I so wanted to quit after round 2) this I told my ONC that 4 rounds will be enough for me.  I justify this because the tamoxifen will give us ER+ gals the greatest benefit, so starting that as soon as possible might be good??   I think Bdavis has a good point, and we all have different cancers / stages so we really can't generalize. Are you doing a scan before your surgery?  Maybe you could look after 4 rounds and see if it's shrunk enough?  Maybe they could even check with a simple ultrasound to get a rough idea??  I'm hoping that round 3 will be easier.  Also, I think it's accepted that reducing chemo up to 15% can be done without loss of benefit - something to ask ONC.   Good Luck and hang in there. webu - great story, glad you made it home safe.  Hope the time with your daughter was nice.  MaryMeg - we aren't getting much info in the states about what's going on, but we are thinking about all who are suffering.  Kim - YAHOO for making it through AC  and YAHOO for shrinkage.  Good luck with all the doctors appointments.  I too have a strong family history, but came out BRCA1/2 negative. Relieved at that but still beleive there must be a genetic component.  Worried that my sister won't take things seriously because of the negative result.  Any chance we could get a picture or 2 posted of beautiful Hawaii and St John when you guys return?? I'm enjoying my night before the nasty NEULASTA nightmare tomorrow brings.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 02:05AM ScienceGirl wrote: TCx4; round 4 day 12 Tammy and Christine- regarding rads after MX.  I had a BMX, my pathology stated clear margins 1.5mm.  Both my medical onc and breast surgeon said no rads.  After reading some papers I seem to think there is controversy on just how 'clear' the margins need to be, some say 1mm, some say more than 2mm.  So I made an appt with the rad onc just to see what they thought.  She took many factors into consideration, like margins, age (I'm 45), multifocal nature of my disease etc...  So all in all she thinks that radiation can benefit me and I tend to agree with her.  In our conversation she said that she likes to see 3mm margins.  So I will be doing 25 rads starting in about a week (3 wks after last chemo).  This is an adjustment for me, because I was expecting to be done with treatment.  I'm also worried that I'm not recovered from chemo and will that make the fatigue worse??  But everyone assures me that radiation will be much easier than chemo. Chemo was Hard! (and I only did 4 rounds)  I'm going back to work soon and I'm really not looking forward to it. Physically I don't feel ready, (still fatigued, waves of nausea hit me randomly, and I have that weird muscle weakness in my thighs) and mentally I'm drained.  I don't think I will ever do that again.  Lately I've been obsessing about how do the stage 4 folks live their life on chemo?  Will I change my mind about not ever doing chemo again if I one day find myself at stage 4?  I'm wishing you all brighter days and smiles
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2011 08:03PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello everyone, it's great to hear that people are finishing or getting close to being done with chemo.  It's 5 weeks past my last infusion and my hair has started to grow!  It's not a lot, but I can tell it's growing  Like so many others I too am having trouble sleeping.  I tried acupuncture for the first time this week.  I think I slept better that night, I'm going again next week, so I'll see if the better night's sleep repeats.  The practitioner said it would help with the hot flashes too, I hope she's right. I've finished with my second week of radiation, no skin reaction or fatigue yet.  Only problem is the WBC going low, I hope that doesn't worsen over the next 3 weeks
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 05:23PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello All, I've been reading all the posts.  It's so hard to keep up, but I enjoy learning how everyone is doing good and bad. I'm on day 7 of my first of TCx4.  I found out that my WBC are very low.  Somehow I thought I could get through this with no immune boosting shots.  (I still think I'm young-45 and healthy and one day I'll wake up and this will be a dream!)  Also I have oral thrush, yuck.  So I'll be getting some neupogen shots and have to take diflucan. SE - I've been a bit nauseous, but not enough to take the decahedron.  I found that eating crackers got me through.  I have been having abdominal cramps / constipation though, that has been the worst SE for me.  Now that I know I will pretreat for next time.  Feeling very fatigued, just want to sit on the couch and not move.  I have my father in law's 80th birthday party in 3 days, I hope I can make it! Good Luck to all, one day at a time.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 05:32PM ScienceGirl wrote: neupogen pain in my hips feels exactly like when I had Lyme's disease. Queasy stomach feels just like morning sickness. Chemo brain is taking me down Memory Lane
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 03:02PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello all,  I so enjoy reading your posts.  Maybe it's misery loves company or just knowing that you all are making it through so maybe I can too? I'm on TCx4  on day 10 after first treatment I felt alot of 'tingling' in my hands.  It was intermittent, but still, I thought this would maybe come with the last treatment?  Now I'm worried about permanent neuropathy (my mind likes to leap, a tingle to permanent nerve damage)  Anyone else?? I was 44 at dx and my mom had BC, but I was still really shocked.  I can't imagine how shocked you younger girls were.  This is so not an old woman disease?  Maybe a baseline mammo should be recommended at 35?  I just feel angry that young mothers are getting this disease. AliT - I would so love some chemo curls!  I'm looking forward to taking a break from the hair dryer, my hair is thin and straight and the air is so dry this winter it's been a wreck. aimster-good for you! Sounds like I feel a lot better than you do and I can't bring myself to exercise, just the thought of it makes me tired.  You go girl.  Also, chemo #2, that sucks.  Just curious are they giving you a different course than the first time? MaryMeg-advanced mange - I laughed out loud, thanks slcst12-I hope the weight stabilises for you.  I'm lucky that my onc is <10min from my house, so I won't ever have to give myself a shot, but I know that lots of ladies have done it.  I think I read somewhere that the abdomen was a good spot.  Good luck with the part time job. good night everyone
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 03:40AM ScienceGirl wrote: hsgray - What an awful time to get the flu!  I hope the remaining weeks of treatment go much better for you.  I hope you can get a port and that solves the problems for you.  I had a BMX and I get stuck on both sides??? (3 nodes/ 2 nodes)  I ask about the sticks and no one seems to think it's a problem, or maybe they just can't deal with putting IV's in legs?  They look at me like I'm crazy, am I the first to get a BMX? ridiculous Monday I went to work with a scarf.  I decided not to go with my wig.  It looks fine, but I just don't 'feel' right with it on, I actually feel more self conscious with the wig than with a scarf?  I feel like I'm trying to fool everyone that I have hair, weird.   People at work were fine, they were expecting it.  Today I have a welcome breakfast, (our group has moved to a new site) so I will be meeting a lot of new people.  Really bummed that this will be my first impression, must buck up and put on my brave happy face TC#2 is tomorrow.  I told them at work they won't see me for a week.  So releived about this, I won't stress each day about dragging myself in for half a day. Ladies, we are making it through!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 02:51PM ScienceGirl wrote: Everyone looks great bald or rockin the scarf.  I'm loving not having to mess with my hair in the mornings, so easy to just pop a scarf on.  Still not completely bald, day 21 (scalp is less sore then the last few days), cut real short and started wearing the scarves at day 18 after first TC - about 4th day after noticed first shedding. I was worried my 2nd chemo would be postponed due to the ice storm.  The place had a delayed opening at 10:30, I was there when they opened and had the entire place to myself for the whole time.  It was so quiet I got a lot of reading done and had all the nurses to myself : ) Here is a website that lists the 'normal' ranges for wbc, platlets, hemoglobin....  std CBC http://www.neulasta.com/patient/about/blood_counts.html Looks like we are all moving through our treatments, lets hope/pray for no more hospitalizations. Kim
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 01:13PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello all, I got my first Neulasta shot, expected bone pain like I had with the neupogen.  I got no bone pain, but 3hrs after the shot I got chills and a fever and felt terrible for the next 2 days.  It's really dampening my spirits, I'm ready to quit, but I won't DH won't let me.  I know I'll feel pretty good in a couple of days, but this round 2 was really worse than round 1 and not what I expected.  Now I'm scared for round 3.  Then I feel bad because I should be stronger about all of this.  ARGHH.  Maybe this is all compounded by the hair loss  of this week, it's a lot at once.  I guess I can hope that round 2 will be the worst one.  Thanks for letting me vent!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 04:20AM ScienceGirl wrote: I knew you guys would make me feel better! tfinin99-good luck with round 2, I think the mental aspect took me down with my round 2, it was so different than round 1. This feeling of not being 'strong' really hit me hard. I will be thinking of you on Thursday, have you tried Claritin? I haven't, but I might next time. EmilyInOntario- I'm glad you're feeling better, are you on a 14 day or 21 day cycle? My onc said I could take Tylenol for the chills and fever because right after my shot my counts shouldn't have been low that quick. Thank goodness, that helped me get through. The first round I tried with no Neulasta and my WBC went low. Some people can get through with no Neulasta/neupogen? good luck to you ProudMom-glad to hear that you're making it through #3. I think you are right, mentally we have to adjust our expectations of what we can do. Crappy cancer take a hike!! bdavis-Good luck on Tuesday, are you trying Claritin? Glad the wig liner worked. amelia2-My onc said the same thing to me, and I didn't have the Neulasta with round 1 either. I'm lucky that it's very cold now where I live. Everyone is walking around with hats, so it made the initial hat wearing easier. Forget the hot wig, just try to be as comfortable as possible. Yes, this awful, evil chemo with be worth it for all of us!! slcst12-I'm not a wig girl either. I bought a wig with the least amount of hair and it still feels like way too much. I had my treatment on Wed last week too, I told them I might be in on Wed of this week. Not having to drag myself into work has taken the pressure off. Please give yourself the time you need to rest, i hope that's possible for you. Keep swearing @#$%^&&^%$# it really helps ; )
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 04:35PM ScienceGirl wrote: TCx4; round 3 day 7 amyK- YIPEE, AC is over, you did it!  I loved your dance.  Did you feel spring in the air today?  SMILE I asked my onc to test my Vitamin D, don't have the results yet.  I'm a little frustrated with her.  I've gotten oral thrush with each round of chemo and was treated with diflucan.  Went to the dentist today to get the stitch out from getting my tooth pulled and he said he was sure it wasn't thrush.  So I took another medication for nothing?!  On the other hand, she added Emend to the chemo this time and round 3 has definitely been easier than number 2.  My 13yr old daughter made a birthday cake today with her friends for Justin Bieber.  They sang Happy Birthday to him and everything. (I was laughing inside the whole time)  Three neighbor boys put up with the Bieber fever just to get some cake, HA! tsundermann - I hope your feeling OK AliT - I hope the imaging proves that 4 treatments was enough. Hang in there all, we're making it through.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2011 04:14PM ScienceGirl wrote: Emily, good luck with the taxotere/taxol.  My main symptom with the TC was constipation, so I'd sugest a stool softener/laxative starting the day before.  That being said, some people get diaherra, so you just don't know!!  Bdavis, sounds like you were able to enjoy your trip, that's great : ) Christine, my tumor was very close to the chest wall, so that probably factors into my post-mastectomy radiation. tsundermann - thanks for your comments, your mom is an inspiration, I hope she continues to do well. I've been getting weird 'warm flushes' not 'hot flashes'.  I think it must be hormonal, but it's not the typical 'flash'.  They are annoying especially when it wakes me everynight, but I remind myself that less estrogen is a GOOD thing. good luck to all this week, I'll let you know the moment my hair starts growing (believe me i'll be checking everyday in a couple of weeks)
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 09:51AM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello Everyone, (TCx4 start 1/13; cycle 2 day 9)- good idea Emily Welcome to all the newbies and a big thank you to Renrel for posting - we need all the encouragement we can get. tfinn99 - Today is Thurs, I hope your treatment went well.  I got oxycontin for the neupogen bone pain and I took tylenol which helped with the fever/chills I got with the neulasta shot.   Don't suffer through this time, make your onc help with the symptoms!!  {{{HUG}}} 1Miclon - I'm so sorry about what you've been though.  Read some of the survivor stories on this site, always cheers me up. Kadorazio - I'm not wearing my wig at all, just hats and scarves.  Go with what you feel the most comfortable with. My head has finally stopped hurting/ being sensitive, about week and half since the major shedding began.  My husband has a soft brush for his balding head (DD says "Daddy you grew too tall for your hair!) we all used to make fun of him for it, but now I use it too, it feels great. Good luck to all, feel well
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 03:56AM ScienceGirl wrote: TCx4; start 1/13; round 2 day 12 baf4292 - how is your arm feeling? amyK- you are not a wimp, the depths of despair that I felt with round 2 really scared me. I too felt like everyone else was able to cope and what was wrong with me. Then I started to feel better and my mood was lifted as well, I'm still scared of round 3, but I'll do it. We can do this, please listen to JulieH and ProudMom. webu- chemo brain - I don't feel like I've been forgetting things, but I've been almost completely useless at work. I am totally unable to gather my thoughts together to plan an experiment, I can't concentrate. It's really frustrating. tfinn - how are you feeling? EmilyinOntario - YES! My teeth got very sensitive for a couple of days with round 1. It just came and went out of the blue, very strange. Sorry you had to go to the ER. 1Miclon- I've been given the Neupogen shot by several different nurses. One, absolutely no pain and another excruciating. I had a 'good' nurse for the Neulasta and it hardly hurt at all. I'm day 12, round one I was pretty much back to normal, but round 2 it seems like my energy is 100% then an hour later I will be on the couch not able to move? Really variable, like MaryMeg said I too am afraid people will think I'm a Drama Queen.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 02:03AM ScienceGirl wrote: AliT - You are not a wimp - talk to your ONC, make sure he knows your struggling!  (Round 3 will be better than 2 - I'm trying positive thinking, I'll let you know if it works!)

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 03:35AM ScienceGirl wrote: Good Morning Everyone! MaryMeg and JulieH - We have to slow down and take care of ourselves.  Putting my life of hold for the next several months is difficult and it sounds like I don't have even near the schedules that you 2 have! bdavis-thanks for the info on the dexamethasone and fasting.  When I asked my onc, she didn't give much advise?  She is on the young side and managing side effects doesn't seem to be on her radar.  On the other hand I could be a big baby : )   Snow, seems like we're in for a lot this winter.  It's worth it though, I'm a summer girl, so I'd like to be feeling good by then.  I'm in North Jersey GSP135. suz3- Thank you for teaching our kids!  You'll never know how important you are to their parents.  I imagine you'll need lots of energy to deal with the 3-5 set, but at least they will distract you!  Good luck with the wig, as you know, anything can happen! I will try the Biotene mouthwash, thanks. Wishing you all a great day
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 07:26PM ScienceGirl wrote: I made changes to my diet immediately at diagnosis, no sugar, less meat, no dairy, more cruciferous veggies, more exercise, started Vitamin D supplements.  This ALL went out the window when I started feeling bad from the chemo.  Just couldn't  limit what I ate, just had to eat what would not taste terrible.  I will try to go back to the changes after my chemo side effects subside.  Kudos to those who exercised during chemo, that's awesome!  I don't know how you did it!  I lost 30lbs from diagnosis to first chemo - all of 8 weeks(190 to 160, I'm 5'6").  I asked the onc if we should worry about this and she said "Oh, we don't need to worry yet"  Later I realized that I'm not even close to my ideal weight, she should have just said that we'll worry after 30 more pounds come off!!  Geez, take it easy on a chunky girl, 30lbs in 9 weeks mostly due to sheer terror.  Oh no concern. jcoutee-good luck with your decision.  I had a BMX with no recon, the right choice for me.  Spend some quiet time with yourself, the answer will come to you.  Once you decide, own your decision and don't second guess yourself.  You know what's best for you! I'm thinking of you all hopefully nearing the end of your chemo.  I start my rads on Monday.  I have my bottle of Tamoxifen, but I think I will wait a week or two to start.  I've been wiped out for a week with an awful cold, just want to get stronger before I throw another variable into the mix.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 03:01PM ScienceGirl wrote: Lorenar and jcoutee - my heart aches that you have joined us here. I hope this board gives you strenth, laughs, and a sense of community like it has given me. Tideknott - I'm on TC also.  I was surprised how quickly taste was effected, even on day 1 things started to taste funny for me.    I'm on day 13 and I think things are about 90% back to normal regarding taste.  Hang in there, I think day 5 and 6 were the worst for me, sounds like you're doing well, I hope it continues.  Otherwise, since day 12 I feel amazingly great!  I think i felt so crappy that just feeling normal is wonderful.  I think next round will be easier, I'll now what symptoms to expect and also look forward to that magic day 12.  ProudMom - crappy is the perfect adjective!  I totally agree about the 'great attitude'  I feel like I have to keep up the front at home and work, it's exhausting!  Listen to MaryMeg and aimeemac, they say it so well.  Vent all you want, doesn't it feel good?  Here's one from me:  On Friday night when my WBC were zero, it's 8 pm and freezing out, my onc called in an antibiotic Rx for me,  hubby was too tired, so I went out to get it myself    REALLY!!  (OK he's usually good, but sometimes I don't know what he's thinking) OK, I have the vision thing too, just a subtle kind of not focusing as good as I should??  What is up with that?  Seems like a lot of us have it.  I haven't heard of this SE before on any of the other boards, anyone?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 05:06PM ScienceGirl wrote: Anniemomofthree Thanks for the info "12 days is too long to be sick"  that never occurred to me, I thought we just had to take whatever it was.  I will be proactive tomorrow when I see my onc and ask her what we can change for next time.  I told her before what my SE's were, she kinda just nodded and wrote it all down, not offering any suggestions.  I will ask for more help.  THANKS!  (I'm on TC, so maybe that explains the vision thing, it's getting annoying)  Good Luck to you in round 2 JulieH, glad you're feeling well today.  Wish you had more time before they BLAST you again, who ever came up with 'dose dense' is a sadistic person.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 03:37AM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello All, It's early here, up at 5am when I got 2 phone calls to tell me that school is closed here in NJ. (I never get to sleep in on snow days?!?) I don't have BRAC1/2 but I  have to wonder about other yet unknown genetic factors.  Mom got her cancer at 48 (3 primaries over 7 yrs) and me at 44 (bilateral primaries).  (very happy with my BMX choice)  Navywife please try not to worry about your kids, get yourself through this, focus on your health.  I know it's hard, I worry about my 13 yr old daughter, both her grandmothers passed from this beast and now her mother has it too.  Birthday #31 this will be in the rear view mirror.  There have been many advances in the last 10 years in treating BC.  When our kids are older, preventitive meds / vaccines / new personalized treatments might make this disease just a blip on the radar and not the shot in the gut that we all got. JulieH - I just have blurry vision, no pain, I think you should call.  Hope you're OK. Amelia2 - I'll have my buzz cut soon.  Good luck  with your first revel to the public!  I tried to wear my sleep cap to bed just incase a lot of hair came out, wouldn't stay on b/c I have too much hair. HA not for long.  Have a wonderful weekend : ) Never heard of Nanaimo bars here in the east.  Yum! but I might kill hubby (diabetes) if I make them at home : ) I hope you all have a wonderful day, keep smiling, or not, whatever you feel like today, just roll with it.

We all just want to do the schedule and be done as soon as possible.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 02:51PM ScienceGirl wrote: I will be starting chemo in the middle of January. Probably TC x 4.  I had synchronous bilateral tumors, mixed ductal/lobular. No node involvement.  Oncotype on the left (1.3cm) was 13 and the tumor on the right (2cm) was 25.  I had a BMX on 11/30 - so glad I went that route because on the right I had the one large tumor and they found 5!! smaller ones!  I've been reading that lobular can often be multifocal.  Feel overwhelmed by information and statistics.  On the other hand, all the stories and encouragment from others who have made it through their chemo really helps.  We can make it through too  : )
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 12:39PM ScienceGirl wrote: moe0279- First let me thank you for your work, I know our kids aren't easy, but you must get lots of good stories out of it!  You just never know what they are going to say/think.  My Tyler says he knows boys from girls by their hair, also he knows the kids names at school by their clothes - amazing that it's easier to memorize their whole wardrobe then remember a face.  anniemomofthree - I am so relieved the first treatment is done.  The waiting is always what makes me crazy.  Looking back on today, I had a great day.  I got to read, listen to music, chat with nice nurses, so much easier than going to work.  I'm lucky I didn't have any reaction to the taxotere.  I feel fine, I know that some SE might hit in a few days, but I decided not to hold my breath, I just going along assuming I will be fine. (Lets see if that works?)  Good Luck to all this month, we can do it!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2011 06:12PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello Ladies, Sorry to post on your forum, but here is an interesting article:  Breast Cancer Tumor Size, Nodal Status, and Prognosis: Biology Trumps Anatomy http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/29/19/2610.full.pdf+html epark - your question "stage IV with small tumors and clear lymph nodes but they still have mets. how is that possible?"  It is certainly possible, the mechanisms of metastasis are not clearly understood.  The article talks about the cancer cell - depending on it's unique mutations / protein expression dictates where it can 'colonize'  or 'seed' a new tumor.  Theoretically cancer cells can pass through the lymph nodes and not stop there.  Also cells can pass in the vascular system too (blood). This is so frustrating that we just don't fully understand this disease.  It would be so much easier if science could tell us exactly the course this awful cancer will take in our bodies.
Posts.Title: ? ON STAGE V AND METS epark epark

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 07:21AM ScienceGirl wrote: Lovelillian - I had a oncotype score of 25.  But I had some other issues, multifocal disease (6 places of cancer on the right) and bilateral tumors (one on left was oncotype 13).  Nodes were negative, but age was younger -44.  I saw 3 oncologists, 2 said they would recommend TCx4 mostly because of my young age, the other said (at MSK) do AC+  DD.  I was presented at the tumor board at my hospital, the consensus was do TCx4 but there were still a couple of oncs who thought no chemo.  So i reluctantly agreed to the TCx4, even though my greatest benefit will come from Tamoxifen.  I've had one round, and it has been harder then expected.  My WBC went to zero, and I got a mild fever, luckily this was treated with antibiotics at home, but if my fever went up 0.2 degrees more I would be in the hospital with IV antibiotics.  From what I read there is 10% mortalitly in people hospitalized for neutropenic fever.  Now I have neuropathy in my hands, just from one treatment, I'm scared it might become permanent.  All this for a treatment that might not even benefit me?   We are all damned if we do and damned if we don't.  Make your decision and own it, then never question yourself.  recurrence or not I'm learning more and more that all we can do is what is best for ourselves at any particular time.
Posts.Title: Anyone with an intermediate oncotype? Lovelillian nem126

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 02:02PM ScienceGirl wrote: Take a deep breath.  Try not to worry about the biopsy, I had a core needle biopsy guided by ultrasound.  It was completely painless except for the small stick of the lidocaine needle.  Also the vast majority (80%) of biopsy's come back benign.  They won't tell you it's cancer until the biopsy results come back.  I'll be thinking of you, please post back on how you're doing.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 10:20PM ScienceGirl wrote: I had tumors on both sides, I had a BMX.  That would have been my choice even with 1 tumor.  If you do both sides, no more mammograms EVER!  (I'm so glad I don't have the stress of that every 6months)  Also, I didn't have reconstruction, so being lopsided wasn't something I wanted, now I have the option of going without breast forms.  I go without forms sometimes at home and when I go to exercise class.  My Mom had multiple lumps in both breasts over several years, she did lumpectomy until the third BC then finally a mastectomy - I'm trying to save myself that same course.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 11:56AM ScienceGirl wrote: Oh My, Sounds very complicated.  I agree with the other posts.  Get yourself to a cancer center and be sure to see a breast surgeon.  DO NOT wait 6 months, if only for your piece of mind to confirm that nothing is wrong.  I know that it's scary, but my breast biopsy was completely painless.  I had an excellent surgeon do a core needle biopsy guided by ultrasound.  Just a tiny prick for some lidocaine and no problem (honestly going to the dentist is worse).  Maybe they won't want to do a biopsy, but maybe an MRI would clear up the confusion.  Please take care of yourself, remember early stage breast cancer is curable.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 08:25PM ScienceGirl wrote: Oh good, I'm glad your on Metformin!  So does your onc contribute the tumor decrease in size to the increased dose of Metformin?  It must be right? How cool is that. My hubby takes it, so I pilfered some of his pills and took it for a month.  My oncologist wasn't really aware of it, so I spent today gathering articles that I will give her tomorrow.  After my chemo is over I'm going to look into getting in one of the clinical trials (taking the chance that I would be in the placebo arm).  Wouldn't that be great if a well studied, low side effect, inexpensive, oral drug would have efficacy in breast cancer. PS-DH gets his metformin for free at QuikChek (a store like 7-11) don't know how they can do that?

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 03:22PM ScienceGirl wrote: I am sorry that you are joining our BC club.  I was diagnosed in Nov'10.  I am 4 wks out from my bilateral mastectomy.  My mother in the early 90's had her first lumpectomy, mid 90's second lumpectomy and by the late 90's she had a mastectomy.  I just figured I would save myself all those surgeries and just do it all at once.  Also I don't think I could have survived the stress of future mammograms and waiting for the results.  It turns out that it was the right choice for me, in addition to the 2cm tumor that showed up on the mammogram, there were FIVE other areas of cancer.  Of course there are many, many women who are cured by lumpectomy and RX, if we only had a crystal ball.....  (note that if you have invasive lobular carcinoma, ILC that tends to be multifocal) Good Luck to you

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2011 10:58PM ScienceGirl wrote: I am also 45 and it's been 6 weeks from my BMX.  I was freaking out, anxious, not sleeping before my surgery.  I got some ativan from my onc, and even though I only took a few, it was a godsend on those few occasions I couldn't calm myself down. I am also, node neg, ER+ and HER2-, and stage 1.  We will get our greatest benefit from blocking estrogen (tamoxifen).  My oncotype score is 25, solidly in the intermediate range.  It is questionable how much benefit I will receive from chemo, I'm guessing a few percentage points.  When we have the data from the TAILORx study we will know how beneficial chemo is for intermediate oncotype scores. I got THREE opinions.  Two recommeded TCx4 and one recommended AC+T dose dense.  I have requested to do TC x 6 after reading many papers and listening to : •Breast Cancer Treatment 2010: Medical Oncology Sara Hurvitz, MD http://www.simmsmanncenter.ucla.edu/information/insights_summaries/insights_summaries.asp I found that getting as much information as possible really helped me accept that I need chemo and helped me gain a sense of control. Let me leave you with something on of the onc's said that really struck me:  "Right now (meaning before recurrence) we have one chance to cure your disease"  Wishing you the lowest possible oncotype score, good luck!
Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 05:34PM ScienceGirl wrote: LuvRVing Good for you, for making your own decision and owing it!  This is our lives and we have the the final say. Regarding diabetes, google "metformin and breast cancer", some interesting stuff.  There are several clinical trials looking at the benefit of the diabetes drug metformin in breast cancer.  I'm sorry to hear about your friend, my Mom also had 3 seperate bouts with breast cancer.  I often wonder if she did a BMX with the first one if she would have had a better outcome, but then I remind myself that she did what was best for her at the time.  That's all any of us can do. All the best to you

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 05:38PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello, you all crack me up! Raro, I've done the shower/cleaning combo too, ha ha, actually works great and you don't get your clothes wet. My shame = one of my bedroom dressers got pulled out from the wall for some reason (some of the clutter on top must have fell behind) - it's been that way for months - we just walk around it. Why don't we just push it back, it would take 30secs. What is wrong with us!?!?! A note about men/floors. We have a roomba (I highly recommend it for hardwood floors, not so much for carpet). My husband is a big tech/gadget guy. The roomba is his new toy, he runs it almost everyday. Our floors have never been cleaner - before he never even noticed the tumbleweeds from our 2 dogs piling up. I'm keeping my mouth shut and just waiting to see how long he will continue with his new 'toy'. Don't get me started about beagles. Ours thinks he's king of the world. He sometimes pees in my bed (how awful is that). My husband blames me and thinks he does it because I yell at him to get off the bed. So now when I catch him (beagle not husband) in the bed I have to talk very nice to him and give him a treat to get off. My next life I want to come back as a beagle, he is really the boss in my house for sure. Thanks for the laugh and have a good night,

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 06:40PM ScienceGirl wrote: I agree that dairy should be eliminated from the diet of those of us with BC.  Milk is for infants.  We didn't evolve drinking milk as adults we have been brainwashed to beleive that it's part of a healthy diet.   It doesn't make sense - we are drinking the breast milk of another species as adults.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2016 06:06PM ScienceGirl wrote: Hello All, I just finished the book, I'm a little behind. I really loved it immensely. What a wonderful loving man that you wouldn't never guess if you judged him by his gruff manner. As for books, I'm open to anything. "the storied life...." sounds good. Here are some of my favorites: The Glass Castle by Jeanette Walls Behind the Beautiful Forevers: Life, Death and Hope in a Mumbai Undercity by Katherine Boo Happy reading! Kim
